docs.title: Jane
docs.text:
Zero‑side‑effect normalization and validation helpers for JavaScript.

Jane is a small, clarity‑first helper library for normalizing, validating, and safely parsing unknown input in JavaScript and TypeScript.

It’s built for developers who want predictable behavior, composable pipelines, and zero surprises — without schema systems, decorators, or framework lock‑in.

Jane is intentionally small. Intentionally explicit. Intentionally boring in all the right ways.

docs.title: Why Jane?
docs.text:
Most validation libraries try to be everything: schema builders, type generators, transformers, parsers, refiners, and runtime type systems.

Jane takes the opposite approach.

Jane is:

  • Pure: No side effects, no hidden mutations.
  • Deterministic: Same input, same output, every time.
  • Composable: Build pipelines with pipe().
  • Zero‑dependency: No runtime weight.
  • Framework‑agnostic: Works in Node, serverless, workers, Express, Fastify, Bun, Deno.
  • Focused: Normalization → validation → result.

If you want a dependable “standard library” for data sanity, Jane is your girl.

docs.title: Who is Jane for?
docs.text:
Jane is designed for developers who:

  • Prefer explicit, predictable behavior over magic.
  • Want pure functions instead of schema DSLs.
  • Need safe parsing for config, requests, queries, and internal boundaries.
  • Value clarity and maintainability in long‑lived codebases.
  • Dislike validators that throw.
  • Want small, composable building blocks instead of monolithic schemas.

If you’ve ever written your own tiny normalizers and validators because existing libraries felt too heavy — Jane was built for you.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: npm install @steven-clements/jane

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text:
Documentation is available at:

  • Project overview
  • Reference
  • Contributing

docs.title: License
docs.text:
Jane is licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0.

http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0

docs.title: Author
docs.text:
Steven "Chris" Clements

Designed for clarity, composability, and long‑term maintainability.

docs.title: Follow the development workflow
docs.text:
Jane follows a clarity‑first, contract‑driven workflow. Every change begins with an explicit description of the intended behavior before any implementation work is done.

The workflow is:

  1. Write a reference topic

    Describe the module’s purpose, inputs, outputs, constraints, and edge cases in docs/reference/.

    The reference topic is the human‑readable contract.

  2. Write the tests

    Translate your reference topic into executable expectations using Vitest.

    Tests should cover:

    • Expected behavior.
    • Invalid inputs.
    • Edge cases.
    • Type‑level expectations (if applicable).

    Tests are the executable contract.

  3. Write the implementation

    Implement the module so that it satisfies the spec and passes all tests.

    Keep modules small, explicit, and free of side effects.

  4. Update documentation

    If the change affects public behavior, update the relevant docs in docs/.

  5. Commit using semantic messages

    Use Conventional Commits to ensure automated releases and changelog updates:

    • feat: for new features
    • fix: for bug fixes
    • docs: for documentation changes
    • refactor: for internal changes
    • test: for test‑only changes
    • chore: for non‑code tasks

This workflow ensures that behavior is defined before it is implemented, tests reflect the intended contract, and the codebase remains predictable and maintainable.

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text:
• Development workflow
  • Restricted files and directories

docs.title: Restricted repo files
docs.text:
This project uses automated tooling for releases, formatting, documentation, and configuration.

To keep the repository stable and predictable, certain files must not be edited in pull requests unless explicitly requested by a maintainer.

docs.title: Do not modify these files
docs.text:
• CHANGELOG.md: Automatically generated by the release pipeline. Any manual edits will be overwritten.
  • CODEOWNERS: Defines review and approval rules. Changes require maintainer approval and are not accepted through general PRs.

  • LICENSE: Legal document. Only maintainers may update it.

  • Release and automation configs:

These files are part of the automated release and CI/CD pipeline and must remain stable:

  • .releaserc or release.config.*
  • .github/workflows/*
  • package.json (release‑related fields)

  • semantic-release configuration

  • Formatting and linting configs:

These define the project’s formatting and linting rules:

  • prettier.config.*
  • eslint.config.*
  • .editorconfig
  • tsconfig.json

  • vitest.config.*

  • Root‑level configuration files:

Unless a maintainer requests a change, do not modify files at the repository root (except README.md and mkdocs.yml).

docs.title: Allowed areas for contributions
docs.text:
Most contributions should be limited to:

  • mkdocs.yml — documentation site navigation
  • README.md — General project information (raise the bar!).
  • src/ — implementation
  • tests/ — test suites
  • docs/ — documentation
  • coverage/ — generated coverage artifacts (rarely edited manually)

docs.title: Exceptions
docs.text:
If a change to a restricted file is required to fix a bug, improve documentation, or resolve a configuration issue, please open an issue first.

A maintainer will confirm whether the change is appropriate before a PR is opened.

This policy ensures:

  • Consistent automation.
  • Predictable releases.
  • Stable contributor experience.
  • Clear separation between code and infrastructure.

docs.title: Reference
docs.text:
The Reference section documents every helper in Jane. Each page includes a clear description, the function signature, parameter tables, return shapes, examples, and notes. All helpers follow the same predictable structure so you can find what you need quickly.

Use this section when you already understand the concepts and workflows, and you need precise details about a specific helper.

docs.title: What’s included
docs.text: Jane includes several categories of helpers. Each category has its own index page and detailed entries for every function.

docs.title: Type guards
docs.text:
Helpers that check types and shapes without throwing.

Use these when you need safe branching logic.

Learn more

docs.title: How to read this section
docs.text:
Each helper is documented with:

  • A short description.
  • The function signature.
  • A parameter table.
  • The return shape.
  • Examples.
  • Notes and edge cases.

Every entry is self‑contained and predictable. You can read them in any order.

docs.title: Type guards
docs.text:
Type guards help you safely branch logic and validate shapes without throwing exceptions. They return simple booleans and never mutate input. Use them when you need to confirm a value’s type before running a normalization or validation step.

Type guards are pure, predictable, and consistent. They make your workflows easier to read and easier to reason about.

docs.title: Available type guards
docs.text:
Each type guard has its own reference page with examples and edge cases.

  • isArray: Checks whether a value is an array.
  • isBoolean: Checks whether a value is a boolean.
  • isDate: Checks whether a value is a date.
  • isEnumValue: Checks whether a value is an enum value.
  • isFunction: Checks whether a value is a function.
  • isInteger: Checks whether a value is an integer.
  • isNonEmptyString: Checks for a non‑empty string.
  • isNumber: Checks whether a value is a number.
  • isObject: Checks whether a value is an object.
  • isPlainObject: Checks whether a value is a plain object.
  • isPort: Checks whether a value is a valid TCP/UDP port number.
  • isPromise: Checks whether a value is a promise.
  • isRecord: Checks whether a value is a record.
  • isString: Checks whether a value is a string.
  • isTimestamp: Checks whether a value is a timestamp.

docs.title: When to use type guards
docs.text:
Use type guards when:

  • You need to branch logic based on type.
  • You want to avoid exceptions.
  • You want predictable behavior in pipelines.
  • You need to confirm a value’s shape before normalization.
  • You want to write defensive code without clutter.

Type guards are the simplest building blocks in Jane. They help you write clear, explicit workflows.

docs.title: isArray
docs.text: Checks whether a value is an array. This helper never throws and never mutates input. Use it when you need to confirm that a value is an array before running normalization or validation.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isArray(value: unknown): value is unknown[]

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. This helper performs a strict typeof check and only returns true for finite primitive integers.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is an array.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isArray([])              // true
isArray([1, 2, 3])       // true
isArray(["a", "b"])      // true

isArray({})              // false
isArray(null)            // false
isArray("hello")         // false
isArray(123)             // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper uses Array.isArray internally.
  • Use normalizeArray if you need to ensure a value becomes an array.
  • Use normalizeStringArray if you need an array of strings.
  • Use validateArray if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isBoolean
docs.text: Checks whether a value is a boolean. This helper never throws and never mutates input. Use it when you need to confirm boolean types before running normalization or validation.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isBoolean(value: unknown): value is boolean

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. This helper performs a strict typeof check and only returns true for finite primitive integers.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a boolean.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isBoolean(true)        // true
isBoolean(false)       // true
isBoolean(0)           // false
isBoolean("true")      // false
isBoolean(null)        // false
isBoolean(undefined)   // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper does not coerce truthy or falsy values.
  • Use normalizeBoolean if you need to convert values into booleans.
  • Use validateBoolean if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isDate
docs.text: Checks whether a value is a valid Date instance. This helper ensures the value is a Date object and that it represents a valid timestamp. It never throws and never mutates input.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text:
function isDate(value: unknown): value is Date
Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must be a Date instance with a valid timestamp to return true.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a Date instance and value.getTime() is not NaN.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isDate(new Date())                 // true
isDate(new Date("2020-01-01"))     // true

isDate(new Date("invalid"))        // false
isDate(Date.now())                 // false
isDate("2020-01-01")               // false
isDate(null)                       // false
isDate({})                         // f

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper rejects invalid dates such as new Date("invalid").
  • Use normalizeDate if you need to convert values into Date instances.
  • Use validateDate if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isEnumValue
docs.text: Checks whether a value is one of the allowed enum values. This helper works with both numeric and string enums. It never throws and never mutates input. Use it when you need to confirm that a value belongs to a specific enum before running normalization or validation.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text:
function isEnumValue<T extends Record<string, unknown>>(
  enumObject: T,
  value: unknown
): value is T[keyof T]

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description enumObject Record<string, unknown> The enum-like object whose values define the allowed set. value unknown The value to check. Must match one of the enum’s values to return true.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is included in Object.values(enumObject).
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
enum Color {
  Red = "red",
  Blue = "blue",
}

isEnumValue(Color, "red")     // true
isEnumValue(Color, "blue")    // true
isEnumValue(Color, "green")   // false
isEnumValue(Color, 123)       // false

enum Status {
  Active = 1,
  Disabled = 2,
}

isEnumValue(Status, 1)        // true
isEnumValue(Status, 3)        // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Works with both string and numeric enums.
  • Uses Object.values(enumObject).includes(value) internally.
  • Use normalizeEnum if you need to convert values into enum values.
  • Use validateEnum if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isFunction
docs.text: Checks whether a value is a function. This helper never throws and never mutates input. Use it when you need to confirm callable values before running logic that expects a function.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text:
function isFunction(value: unknown): value is Function
Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must be a callable function to return true.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a function.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isFunction(() => {})        // true
isFunction(function () {})  // true
isFunction(class X {})      // true

isFunction({})              // false
isFunction(null)            // false
isFunction("hello")         // false
isFunction(123)             // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper does not check arity or function type (arrow, async, generator, constructor, etc.).
  • Use it before invoking a value to avoid runtime errors.
  • Use tap or other functional helpers if you need to run side‑effect‑free callbacks inside pipelines.

docs.title: isInteger
docs.text: Checks whether a value is a finite integer. This helper never throws and never mutates input. Use it when you need to confirm integer types before running normalization or validation.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isInteger(value: unknown): value is number

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. This helper performs a strict typeof check and only returns true for finite integers.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a finite integer.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isInteger(42)          // true
isInteger(0)           // true
isInteger(-10)         // true
isInteger(3.14)        // false
isInteger(NaN)         // false
isInteger(Infinity)    // false
isInteger("123")       // false
isInteger(null)        // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper uses Number.isInteger internally, which rejects NaN, Infinity, and -Infinity.
  • Use normalizeInteger if you need to convert values into integers.
  • Use validateInteger if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isNonEmptyString
docs.text: Checks whether a value is a primitive, non‑empty string. This helper never throws and never mutates input. It performs a strict typeof check and does not trim or normalize the value.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isNonEmptyString(value: unknown): value is string

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown Checks whether a value is a primitive string with length > 0, without trimming or normalization.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true: If the value is a primitive string with length greater than 0.
  • false Otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isNonEmptyString("hello")            // true
isNonEmptyString(" ")                // true (whitespace counts as non-empty)
isNonEmptyString("")                 // false
isNonEmptyString(123)                // false
isNonEmptyString(null)               // false
isNonEmptyString(undefined)          // false
isNonEmptyString(new String("x"))    // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper does not trim whitespace.
  • Zero‑width characters still count as non‑empty.
  • This helper returns false for String objects (e.g., new String("x")).
  • Use normalizeNonEmptyString if you need trimming and conversion.
  • Use validateNonEmptyString if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isNonNegativeNumber
docs.text:
Checks whether a value is a non‑negative number. A non‑negative number is defined as a finite number greater than or equal to zero. Fractional values are allowed.

This helper never throws and never mutates input. Use it when you need to confirm that a value is suitable for ranges, durations, sizes, or any domain where zero or positive numeric values are valid.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isNonNegativeNumber(value: unknown): value is number

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: | Name | Data type | Description | | value | unknown | The value to check. Must be a finite number >= 0 to return true. |

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a finite number greater than or equal to zero.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isNonNegativeNumber(0)        // true
isNonNegativeNumber(3.14)     // true
isNonNegativeNumber(100)      // true

isNonNegativeNumber(-1)       // false
isNonNegativeNumber(NaN)      // false
isNonNegativeNumber(Infinity) // false

isNonNegativeNumber("0")      // false
isNonNegativeNumber(0n)       // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper does not coerce strings or other types into numbers.
  • Use normalizeNonNegativeNumber if you need coercion or fallback behavior.
  • Use validateNonNegativeNumber if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.
  • Big integers are intentionally rejected to avoid silent cross‑type numeric behavior.

docs.title: isNumber
docs.text: Checks whether a value is a finite primitive number. This helper never throws and never mutates input. Use it when you need to confirm numeric types before running normalization or validation.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isNumber(value: unknown): value is number

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. This helper performs a strict typeof check and only returns true for finite primitive integers.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a finite primitive number
  • false otherwise

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isNumber(42)          // true
isNumber(0)           // true
isNumber(-3.14)       // true
isNumber(NaN)         // false
isNumber(Infinity)    // false
isNumber("123")       // false
isNumber(null)        // false
isNumber(undefined)   // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper rejects NaN, Infinity, and -Infinity because they are not meaningful numeric values.
  • Use isInteger if you need to confirm integer values.
  • Use normalizeNumber if you need to convert values into numbers.
  • Use validateNumber if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isObject
docs.text: Checks whether a value is an object, excluding null and arrays. This helper never throws and never mutates input. Use it when you need to confirm that a value is a non‑null, non‑array object before running normalization or validation.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isObject(value: unknown): value is object

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must be a non‑null, non‑array object to return true.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is an object, not null, and not an array.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isObject({})                     // true
isObject({ a: 1 })               // true
isObject(Object.create(null))    // true

isObject([])                     // false
isObject(null)                   // false
isObject("hello")                // false
isObject(123)                    // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper excludes arrays by design.
  • Use isPlainObject if you need to confirm Object.getPrototypeOf(value) === Object.prototype.
  • Use normalizeObject if you need to ensure the value becomes an object.
  • Use validateObject if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isPlainObject
docs.text: Checks whether a value is a plain object. A plain object is one created with {} or new Object(), where the prototype is exactly Object.prototype. This helper excludes null, arrays, class instances, and objects with custom prototypes. It never throws and never mutates input.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isPlainObject(value: unknown): value is object

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must be a non‑null object whose prototype is exactly Object.prototype to return true

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a non‑null object with Object.prototype as its prototype.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isPlainObject({})                     // true
isPlainObject({ a: 1 })               // true
isPlainObject(new Object())           // true

isPlainObject([])                     // false
isPlainObject(null)                   // false
isPlainObject(Object.create(null))    // false
isPlainObject(new Date())             // false
isPlainObject(class X {})             // false
isPlainObject(new (class Y {})())     // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper is stricter than isObject.
  • Use isObject if you only need to exclude null and arrays.
  • Use normalizeObject if you need to ensure the value becomes an object.
  • Use validateObject if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isPort
docs.text: Checks whether a value is a valid TCP/UDP port number. A port is defined as an integer between 0 and 65535 (inclusive). This helper never throws and never mutates input. It performs strict type checks and does not coerce strings or other values into numbers.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isPort(value: unknown): value is number

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must be an integer between 0 and 65535 (inclusive) to return true.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is an integer within the valid port range.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isPort(0)        // true
isPort(80)       // true
isPort(65535)    // true

isPort(-1)       // false
isPort(70000)    // false
isPort(3.14)     // false
isPort("80")     // false
isPort(null)     // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper does not coerce strings (e.g., "80" is invalid).
  • This helper requires the value to be a primitive number.
  • Use normalizePort if you need to coerce values into ports.
  • Use validatePort if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isPositiveInteger
docs.text:
Checks whether a value is a positive integer. A positive integer is defined as a finite number with no fractional component and greater than zero.

This helper never throws and never mutates input. Use it when you need to confirm that a value is suitable for count‑based operations, array lengths, pagination, or any domain where only strictly positive whole numbers are valid.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isPositiveInteger(value: unknown): value is number

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must be a finite integer greater than zero to return true.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a finite integer greater than zero.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isPositiveInteger(1)        // true
isPositiveInteger(42)       // true

isPositiveInteger(0)        // false
isPositiveInteger(-1)       // false
isPositiveInteger(1.5)      // false
isPositiveInteger(NaN)      // false
isPositiveInteger(Infinity) // false

isPositiveInteger("1")      // false
isPositiveInteger(1n)       // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper does not coerce strings or other types into numbers.
  • Use normalizePositiveInteger if you need coercion or fallback behavior.
  • Use validatePositiveInteger if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.
  • Big integers are intentionally rejected to avoid silent cross‑type numeric behavior.

docs.title: isPromise
docs.text:
Checks whether a value is a Promise‑like object. This helper never throws and never mutates input. It performs a structural check to confirm that the value is an object with a callable then method.

Use it when you need to confirm that a value behaves like a Promise before awaiting or chaining it.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isPromise(value: unknown): value is Promise<unknown>

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must be a non‑null object with a callable then method to return true.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a Promise‑like object.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isPromise(Promise.resolve(123))     // true
isPromise(new Promise(() => {}))    // true

isPromise({ then: () => {} })       // true (Promise-like)
isPromise({})                       // false
isPromise(null)                     // false
isPromise("hello")                  // false
isPromise(123)                      // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper checks for Promise‑like values, not just native Promises.
  • A value is considered a Promise if it is an object with a callable then method.
  • Use normalizePromise if you need to convert values into Promises.
  • Use validatePromise if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isRecord
docs.text: Checks whether a value is a record-like object. That is, a non‑null, non‑array object whose keys are strings. This helper never throws and never mutates input. Use it when you need to confirm that a value is suitable for string‑keyed object operations before running normalization or validation.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isRecord(value: unknown): value is Record<string, unknown>

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must be a non‑null, non‑array object to return true.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a non‑null, non‑array object.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isRecord({})                     // true
isRecord({ a: 1 })               // true
isRecord(Object.create(null))    // true
isRecord(new (class X {})())     // true

isRecord([])                     // false
isRecord(null)                   // false
isRecord("hello")                // false
isRecord(123)                    // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper is broader than isPlainObject because it allows any prototype.
  • Use isPlainObject if you need to confirm Object.prototype as the prototype.
  • Use normalizeRecord if you need to ensure the value becomes a record.
  • Use validateRecord if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.

docs.title: isString
docs.text: Checks whether a value is a primitive string. This helper never throws and never mutates input. It performs a strict typeof check and does not coerce values.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isString(value: unknown): value is string

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must be a string (primitive string) to return true.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
• true if the value is a primitive string.
  • false otherwise.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
isString("hello")               // true
isString("")                    // true
isString(123)                   // false
isString(null)                  // false
isString(undefined)             // false
isString({})                    // false
isString([])                    // false
isString(new String("hello"))   // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper does not trim or modify the value.
  • This helper returns false for String objects (for example, new String("x")).
  • Use isNonEmptyString if you need to ensure the string is not empty.
  • Use normalizeString if you need to convert values into strings.

docs.title: isTimestamp
docs.text: Checks whether a value is a valid numeric timestamp. A timestamp is defined as a finite number representing milliseconds since the Unix epoch. This helper never throws and never mutates input. It performs a strict type check and does not coerce strings or other values into numbers.

docs.title: Signature
docs.text: function isTimestamp(value: unknown): value is number

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Data type Description value unknown The value to check. Must be a finite number representing a valid millisecond timestamp to return true.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
A boolean:

  • true if the value is a finite number and not NaN.
  • false otherwise.

Examples

isTimestamp(Date.now())        // true
isTimestamp(1700000000000)     // true

isTimestamp("1700000000000")   // false
isTimestamp(NaN)               // false
isTimestamp(Infinity)          // false
isTimestamp(null)              // false
isTimestamp({})                // false

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This helper does not validate ranges (e.g., future or past limits).
  • This helper does not accept strings, even numeric ones.
  • Use normalizeTimestamp if you need to coerce values into timestamps.
  • Use validateTimestamp if you need a Result<T> instead of a boolean.
